unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Interpreting $T$-Interval
question_text:
A television programmer at a local news station surveyed the last $30$ weekday nights and recorded the number of viewers on the $10$ p.m. news.
The programmer constructed a one-sample T-interval to find that there is somewhere between $470{,}000$ to $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ with $95\%$ confidence.
Which of the following statements could be valid interpretations of the interval?

choices.text: There is a $2.5\%$ probability that more than $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watch the weekday nightly news.
There are most likely somewhere near $500{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watching the weekday nightly news.
There is a $95\%$ chance that between $470{,}000$ and $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watch the weekday nightly news on any given night.
About $95\%$ of nights, this network has between $470{,}000$ and $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watching the weekday nightly news.
In the long run, $95\%$ of people watch the weekday nightly news in this community.

solution:
A confidence interval is used to sample and estimate where the population mean could be.

By constructing an interval of $470{,}000$ to $520{,}000$, we think the mean could be in this range, and we are using a process that gets it right $95\%$ of the time in the long run.

We can assign $95\%$ to the overall process of intervals at that confidence level catching the unknown mean, but we can never assign a specific probability to this particular interval.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.

Choice 'A' is incorrect. We can never assign a probability to a particular confidence interval.

Choice 'C' is incorrect for the same reason; we can never assign a probability to a particular confidence interval.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Intervals attempt to catch the unknown mean, and cannot do anything else.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. This interval attempts to catch the unknown mean amount of people watching this program, and does not deal with proportions.
